skill.name: wp-playground
skill.description: WordPress Playground for instant browser-based WordPress testing. Use for quick demos, plugin testing, or ephemeral development environments without Docker.
skill.summary: WordPress Playground for instant browser-based WordPress testing. Use for quick demos, plugin testin...
skill.author: CrazySwami

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation and JSON blueprint configuration files. No executable code, no network requests, no file system access, and no command execution capabilities. The blueprints are declarative configurations for WordPress Playground that define plugin/theme installations and site settings. All content matches the stated purpose of providing WordPress testing environments.

content.value_statement: Setting up WordPress for testing requires Docker or server configuration. WordPress Playground creates instant, ephemeral environments using WebAssembly directly in your browser without any setup required.
actual_capabilities: Create ephemeral WordPress environments in the browser
Configure site options and settings programmatically
Run PHP code within the playground environment
Execute WP-CLI commands for site management
limitations: Data is lost when the browser closes (ephemeral sessions)
Performance is slower than native PHP servers
Email sending and cron scheduling are not supported

use_cases.title: Quick Plugin Testing
use_cases.description: Test plugins in a clean WordPress environment without Docker setup. Share snapshots with clients for review.

use_cases.title: Theme Preview
use_cases.description: Mount a local theme directory and see instant updates in the browser. No server restart needed.

use_cases.title: Client Demos
use_cases.description: Create pre-configured blueprints with client-specific plugins and settings. Share URL for instant demos.

output: Installed plugins: WooCommerce, WordPress SEO, Admin Site Enhancements
Note: Session data is ephemeral and will be lost when you close the browser

best_practices: Export snapshots before closing to save your test data
Use specific PHP and WordPress versions for compatibility testing
Create separate blueprints for different testing scenarios
anti_patterns: Using Playground for production data or permanent deployments
Testing email-dependent features without proper mocking
Assuming full WP-CLI functionality is available

faq.question: Which WordPress and PHP versions are supported?
faq.answer: Playground supports WordPress from version 3.0 onward and PHP versions 5.4 through 8.3. Specify versions in your blueprint.

faq.question: How long does a Playground session last?
faq.answer: Sessions last as long as the browser tab remains open. Close the tab and your data is lost. Export snapshots to preserve environments.

faq.question: Can I use Playground with my local plugins and themes?
faq.answer: Yes. Use the --auto-mount flag to mount your current directory or use --mount to specify custom paths for development.

faq.question: Is my data safe in WordPress Playground?
faq.answer: Playground runs entirely in your browser using WebAssembly. No data is sent to external servers except to wordpress.org for plugin/theme downloads.

faq.question: Why are some features not working in my test environment?
faq.answer: Playground has limitations: no email sending, limited networking, and reduced WP-CLI support. Use Docker for full-featured testing.
